newsitem.title: UK: Britain racing to make up lost time in Europe.
newsitem.headline: Britain racing to make up lost time in Europe.

text.p: The new Labour government is racing to make up for lost time in Europe by adopting a much more conciliatory tone but it will be some time before Britain gains the influence it is seeking, analysts and diplomats said.

Labour, determined to end the festering antagonism which marred relations with the European Union during the last years of Conservative rule, has already unveiled a raft of measures designed to show the bad old days are gone.

And new Foreign Secretary Robin Cook hardly bothered to rearrange the pens on his desk before he shot off on Wednesday for a one-day visit to France and Germany, two European powerhouses which had long given up on the Conservatives.
Cook said Britain intended to play a leading role in Europe and wanted to work with its partners to reform the 15-nation bloc at a crucial EU summit in Amsterdam next month.

But German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel adopted a cooler tone, dismissing suggestions Britain could immediately join the dominant well-established Franco-German partnership which is the driving force behind the European Union.

"Inside the EU, the French and Germans feel happier about working in a tandem. They have been used to having the other big European country against them," said a political analyst at one major Western embassy.
Experts said that although Paris and Bonn would be delighted by the new noises from London, they would require firm evidence of Britain's new intentions.

"You need more than a positive tone. Being at the heart of Europe implies certain behaviour and actions. We shall see," a senior official at the EU's executive commission told the Financial Times newspaper.
And this could cause problems, since Labour's line on major EU issues does not differ much from that of the Conservatives.

The new government intends to wait and see on whether to join a single currency, has refused to sign an agreement on dropping border controls and wants to overhaul the way the EU controls its fishing industry.

"There isn't a lot of change when you really get down to fundamentals, even on Europe and the need to cooperate," said Colonel Terence Taylor, deputy director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies think-tank.
Taylor said Labour still stood a good chance of defusing some of the tensions stoked up by the Conservatives.
"This can be achieved with change of style which was not achieved by previous administration," he told Reuters.
Sir Timothy Garden, director of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, said Labour was unlikely to take any radical steps in the near future.
"I would have thought we'd see a more constructive engagement in Europe with some changes in approach to issues which are not directly counter to national interests," he said.
Labour also has to deal with a protracted row over a damaging EU ban on beef exports imposed last year after fears that mad cow disease could spread to humans.

"The great question is what happens later this month in Amsterdam. They can duck some things, but they will have to start looking at hard decisions. Fishing could be a problem and beef certainly will be," said the diplomat.
"The question is not: Are Labour going to get what they want?' It is: Are they going to give?'"

Labour's new tone on Europe was reflected in Wednesday's appointment of British Petroleum chairman Sir David Simon -- a strong supporter of a single European currency -- as minister for trade and competitiveness in Europe.

And Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown took a major step on Tuesday towards fulfilling requirements laid down for a single European currency by giving the Bank of England freedom to set interest rates.
But European partners will still want to see more evidence that a Labour administration can make a difference.
"Labour can't surprise anyone tomorrow, but perhaps they can surprise in six months' time. They need to do a good job of selling their arguments in Europe," said the diplomat.
